page.title: 06St Mary's Whaddon
page.content: Seven counties can be seen from the top of the church, built high on a ridge and completed in the 12th century. The nave and aisles finish with plain parapets, the chancel is gable roofed and plain. Of particular interest is one piece of capital depicting two peacocks quarrelling over a morsel. There is a duplicate in a church in Normandy and it seems possible the same Norman workman carved both. The 13th century font is tub-shaped on four shafts separated by vertical bands of dog tooth. Two rare wooden alms shovels are owned by the church. They have been removed for safe keeping after the helmet and sword of Arthur, Lord Grey de Wilton, who died in 1595 were stolen. The Victorian windows were by Kemp, whose signature of peacocks' feathers can be seen on the angels' wings.
